qas.question: Lebanese people of what religion sometimes consider Lebanese to be a distinct language?
In what language are Lebanese laws written?
During the Lebanese Civil War, what language did Lebanese Christians sometimes use officially?
What language is Lebanese closely related to?
What script did Lebanese Christians sometimes use to write Lebanese Arabic during the civil war?
Where is Lebanese considered a dialect and not a distinct language?
During which war did Christians us Latin exclusively?
In which form are all Christian laws written?
In which form may Latin script be conducted?
In which form is Lebanese script written?

context: In <b5_0>Lebanon<b5_0/>, a part of the <a0_0>Christian<a0_0/> population considers "Lebanese" to be in some sense a distinct language from <a1_0><a3_0>Arabic<a3_0/><a1_0/> and not merely a dialect. During the <b6_0>civil war<b6_0/> Christians often used <a2_0>Lebanese Arabic<a2_0/> officially, and sporadically used the <a4_0>Latin<a4_0/> script to write Lebanese, thus further distinguishing it from Arabic. All Lebanese laws are written in the <b7_0><b9_0>standard literary form of Arabic<b9_0/><b7_0/>, though parliamentary debate may be conducted in <b8_0>Lebanese Arabic<b8_0/>.
